instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01326: What is 820-01326? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP1V8_SSD0: What is PP1V8_SSD0? PP1V8_SSD0 is a power rail responsible for powering the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on newer Macbook Pros.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01326</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Have this board that's not powering up. I'm using the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> schematic also as it appears to be the same as this board, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01326</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Anyway, i get PP20V and current pull when battery is connected, indicating battery charge and no current with battery removed. I'm still a bit rusty with these newer macbook's and the power sequence. Only thing i've found so far is 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at 0v 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 3.3v.

Shouldn't <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> be at 3.3 as well since AWAKE is up? Any suggestions on what to check.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01326</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
As always when deal with T2 machine, should start with DFU mode.

If all SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages are present, the board should be detected in Apple Configurator 2.
You should check these voltages only if is not detected; save time this way.

Power on diagrams available for 01055 and 01598 boards; should be sufficient for other T2 boards diagnostic.
If don't find them on the forum, search logi.wiki webpage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01326</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: All SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages are present. I did try DFU mode revive and kept getting errors. When i first plugged in to my system, configurator 2 show that the MacBook pro was in recovery mode. [ATTACH type="full"]60139[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01326</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: looking a little close, found corrosion at <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> and surround components, along with <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> and surrounding components. Somehow i missed these. Let me clean these up and hopefully this is what's causing my issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01326</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: SSD must be in working state; T2 has its dedicated partition there!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01326</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
After cleaning up the corrosion, i'm still not able to get past T2 error. Getting a different T2 error now (see picture). Checked the voltages from the chips affected by the corrosion, <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> and <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>

<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> - 2.5
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL> - 0.98
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL> - 1.8
[ATTACH type="full"]60147[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01326</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: More damage caused by corrosion probably...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01326</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Ultrasonic the board then try again - theres probably crap underneath one or more chips.
